abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the Structural Adjustment
            Loan/Credit for India was satisfactory. The project achieved
            its objectives, its impact on institutional development has
            been substantial, sustainability is likely, and the
            performance of both the Bank and Borrower was satisfactory.
            The main lesson that can be learned from this project is
            that structural reforms can be successfully introduced in a
            democratic society such as India, provided that such reforms
            are cognizant of: 1) the need to undertake timely and
            decisive actions to restore macroeconomic stability,
            particularly to bring fiscal deficits under control; 2) the
            importance of formulating and announcing such structural
            changes in a time-bound manner to signal the
            Government's commitment and provide an anchor for
            private sector expectations; and 3) the imperative of
            marshalling the political support and cooperation of various
            interest groups, particularly organized labor, through
            consultation and actions to alleviate transitional social costs.

5080594.majtheme: Economic management,Trade and integration,Financial and private sector development

abstracts.cdata!:
The Structural Adjustment Loan/Credit
            Project will support the initial phase of the
            Government's program of macroeconomic stabilization and
            structural reform. In addition to a major fiscal adjustment
            effort, the main areas covered by the program are: (a)
            deregulation of domestic industry and promotion of foreign
            direct investment, (b) liberalization of the trade regime,
            (c) reform of domestic interest rates coupled with measures
            to strengthen capital markets and institutions, and (d)
            initiation of public enterprise reform.
